body_content.explanation:
past simple and past participle of 
crush
to press something very hard so that it is broken or its shape is destroyed:
examples: The package had been badly crushed in the post.
Add three cloves of crushed garlic.
His arm was badly crushed in the car accident.

body_content.explanation: to press paper or cloth so that it becomes full of folds and is no longer flat:
examples: My dress got all crushed in my suitcase.

body_content.explanation: If people are crushed against other people or things, they are pressed against them:
examples: Tragedy struck when several people were crushed to death in the crowd.

body_content.explanation: to upset or shock someone badly:
examples: He was crushed by the news of the accident.
The president called upon the army to help crush the rebellion.
France crushed Wales by 36 to 3 in last Saturday's match in Paris.

body_content.explanation: to perform extremely well in a particular situation, competition, etc.:
examples: The company isn't just crushing the commercial realm, it is also innovating corporate culture.
Norway is crushing the Winter Olympics.
They did OK in the semi-finals but crushed it (= did extremely well) in the finals.
